summary:
Tim weighed his options. He was alone at night in some alleyway in Gotham. He had nothing except the clothes left on the ground by someone and the cloak wrapped around his skinny shoulders. His camera was nowhere in sight. His backpack was gone too.

He brought the device to his ear. “Hello?”

Whatever talking had been on the other end of the line immediately cut off at his hesitant greeting.

“Who is this?”
notes:
This was for the I Whump Too Server quote trade event! We were tasked with picking a line from a story by the author we were assigned, then writing a story based on that line. I got Marzue and the line I picked came from her story, of blue feathers and shiny baubles. The line I used is bolded in the story, but I don’t want to spoil anything just yet ;)

I hope you enjoy! :smek:

(See the end of the work for more notes.)

The End

As is, this story is finished. Maybe I’ll come back to write more cute kid Tim in the future or write about him getting aged back up, but maybe not. Just know that Tim gets returned to normal eventually and his family loves and appreciates him whatever size he is.

Thanks for reading! I’ll give my dog extra pets for kudos, bookmarks, and comments.

I hope you all have a wonderful day!
text:
The buzzing by Tim’s ear was really starting to bug him. He was sleeping happily on the—you know—the place he was sleeping.
 
Okay, maybe not that happily because it was kinda damp. And hard. And smelly. And there was that tinny buzzing.
 
And he  wasn’t actually wearing clothes  oh gosh.
 
Tim jerked upright, scrambling his way out of the cloth he was wrapped in. His eyes widened at the surroundings that greeted him—metal dumpsters, tall brick walls rising on either side of him, chain-link fence stretching across one end of the alley. A dark atmosphere that was distinctly Gotham City.
 
The muggy chill in the air made him shiver and he turned back to the pile of cloth he was sitting atop. A black blanket was partially wrapped around the rest of the clothes laying limply on the ground and Tim hesitantly pulled it away from the rest of the bundle. He frowned at the hood-thing with eyes that came with it, along with a logo that looked kind of like a… hook? The hood—on what he now recognized as a cloak—looked a lot like Batman’s cowl, but Gotham’s protector would’ve had the signature bat ears, and he certainly didn’t have a gold logo like that. Tim huffed and wracked his brain trying to place it.  Hero or villain? 
 
That buzzing happened again and broke Tim out of his thoughts. He moved to wrap the cloak around himself—flinching when he brushed over a cut on his arm he didn’t remember getting—before poking around on the ground and unveiling a small plastic earbud. As he brought it closer to his face for inspection—probably a terrible idea if this  was  a villain’s stuff—he realized the buzzing was just tiny voices coming from it.
 
Tim weighed his options. He was alone at night in some alleyway in Gotham. He had nothing except the clothes left on the ground by someone and the cloak wrapped around his skinny shoulders. His camera was nowhere in sight. His backpack was gone too.
 
If Tim was being perfectly honest with himself, if this stuff belonged to a new Gotham Rogue, he knew he’d have a better chance of getting help eventually if he was captured by them than if he was kidnapped or mugged or killed by minor criminals.
 
He brought the device to his ear. “Hello?”
 
Whatever talking had been on the other end of the line immediately cut off at his hesitant greeting.
 
“Who is this?”
 
Tim sucked in a breath.  Oh.  That was Batman. That was  Batman’s  voice.  He was talking to Batman . His heart beat harder in his chest as he barely suppressed the excitement trying to burst out of him. Not only was this a dream come true, this was really the best possible outcome for a situation that easily could’ve ended in various unfortunate ways.
 
He recognized the voice Batman was using as a cross between the one Tim had overheard him using for criminals and the one he used for scared kids. Seeing that he  had  kind of been a scared kid until a moment ago—a feeling that had quickly been overruled by all-encompassing delight now that he’s discovered who exactly he’s managed to contact—Tim was confident in the knowledge that Batman was going to help him.
 
When he opened his mouth again, a little squeak was the only thing that came out. Tim slammed his mouth shut and flushed.  He was talking to Batman  . It should be fine. He knew Batman both in and out of his suit—a secret that  nobody  could know—so he shouldn’t be hard to talk to. So why was Tim feeling so… frozen?
 
Tim felt his face growing warmer. Was he…  embarrassed  to talk to Batman? Now he was embarrassed that he was embarrassed. Unconsciously, he curled smaller, tucking himself more securely into the cloak.
 
 Reeeeal cool, Tim. Your first time meetin’ the big man in person and you’ve gotta act  shy  ? He ain’t gonna bite and ya know it.  He’d never admit it to anyone—it was one of Tim’s biggest secrets—but there were times when Tim pretended he got to have conversations with Robin. Someone to talk to when he was alone, who could give him a pep talk or offer advice. It was only stuff Tim himself could come up with, but pretending that it came from Robin made him feel better.
 
His hands fisted tighter in the deceptively smooth fabric of the cloak encompassing him, and he pushed away his ridiculous bashfulness to speak. “I’m lost and I need some help.”
 
“How did you get on this channel?” Batman asked in his weird halfway-nice voice.
 
Before Tim could answer, another voice—this one electronically distorted—cut in, “Where’s Red Robin? Why do you have his comm?”
 
 Red  Robin? That was a weird thing to specify. Everyone knew who Robin was. Tim looked at the rooftops above him, but he couldn’t see anyone. “Um, there’s no one around here. I just found this…  comm  with some other clothes. He—I’m, um…” Embarrassment colored Tim’s tone as he mumbled, “I’m not wearing anything,” before rushing on, “and he might’ve left this stuff for me while I was asleep.”
 
Tim wasn’t sure his face could  get  any brighter once his next thought hit him. Jason Todd,  Robin , had probably found him naked in an alley. Tim would never be able to look him in the eyes again, and Jason wouldn’t even know why.
 
The comm was silent for a moment until Batman came back to simply say, “Alright. I’ll be at your location in two minutes. Tell me if anyone approaches you,” like it wasn’t a big deal that Batman was about to show up to help him.
 
“Okay,” Tim said faintly.
 
Two minutes. In two minutes he was going to get to see Batman up close. Tim hid his grin in the edge of the cloak. Batman was coming to help him.  Personally .
 
His grin dropped, and he pulled his bottom lip between his teeth to keep it that way. Tim needed to get it together in the next two minutes. He couldn’t be weird and annoying in front of Batman. This was his chance to make a good impression. He had to keep his glee contained.
 
The telltale rumble of the Batmobile came all too soon for Tim’s now-nervously-pounding heart. Burrowing further into the cloak, Tim peered at the approaching figure of Gotham’s protector. He stopped a few feet away, silent and motionless for a long moment before crouching down.
 
Batman’s voice was now completely the one meant for scared kids when he said, “Hello there. Can you tell me your name?”
 
“Timothy Drake.” He hated his full first name, but complete information was probably important for Batman’s records.The Dark Knight pursed his lips and nodded. He then surprised Tim by greeting, “Hi Tim. Could you give me just a moment?” As he turned, Tim felt a smile creep back onto his face. He’d met Mr. Wayne a few times at galas, so he shouldn’t be  that  surprised that he would remember what Tim preferred to be called, but it was nice to have proof someone had paid attention to him.
 
Batman brought his hand up to his ear, and Tim didn’t hear an echo from his own comm when Batman said, “We’ve got a probable Code Dawn for Red Robin. Stand by at the Cave.”
 
“What’s that mean?” Tim asked eagerly, then snapped his mouth shut with a cringe. He’d lasted  two seconds  at keeping that excitement contained. Whoops. Maybe his mom was right when she told him he needed to work harder at being “pleasant” and “unobtrusive”.
 
Yet Batman’s smile wasn’t annoyed at all when he turned back to him. “You don’t need to worry about that, kiddo. Would you feel okay coming with me? I’ve got to check up on something before I can take you home.”
 
Relief flooded Tim. He hadn’t botched this too badly yet . More time with Batman would be literally the best thing ever—except getting to see either the former or current Robin—so  yeah  Tim could wait awhile before going back to his big, empty house. Out loud, however, he spoke with an air of formality, “That should be acceptable.”
 
After bundling Tim into the Batmobile—and wasn’t that another of the coolest things ever—Batman spent some time in the alley using equipment that Tim had no hope of understanding on his own, then bagged the uniform minus the cloak and deposited it in the trunk. Climbing into the Batmobile, Batman gave him another smile. It was way different than the smiles Tim saw him wear at galas, and he’d almost never seen Batman himself smile, so Tim’s chest lit up with warmth. He could almost say the look was… fond.
 
Shortly after he started driving, though, the questions started.
 
“So Tim, I’ve got a couple questions for you. First off, how old are you?”
 
Tim briefly considered lying just so Batman wouldn’t question why a kid his age was alone in downtown Gotham in the middle of the night, but realized that the question was probably just a formality. Give him something easy to answer and he’d be more open to answering harder questions. Like what a kid his age was doing alone in downtown Gotham in the middle of the night.
 
“I’m ten. And—and a half,” Tim bit the inside of his cheek. Why did he have to be so awkward?
 
“Good, that’s a good age. Where do you live?”
 
Tim internally despaired. What happened to spending more time together while Batman “checked something”? Maybe Batman was sick of him, and he was going to take Tim home first. There wasn’t anything Tim could do to stop him though. Turning his attention to the dashboard, Tim quietly gave the address to Drake Manor.
 
Batman hummed quietly and commented, “That’s a long address. Was it hard to learn?”
 
Maybe it was because the sting of disappointment was so sharp, or maybe he was just having a weird night, but an annoyed little scoff escaped Tim before he could cut it off. He hated when people thought he might be dumb just because he was young. “Maybe when I was in kindergarten.”
 
Tim regretted back-talking almost instantly, but when he peeked over at Batman, he saw that the Dark Knight had a smirk on full display. “You’re right; it’s been a few years since then, I guess, so I should’ve figured you would have known it for a while.
 
“I have one last question for you, Tim, before we get where we’re going. Do you remember why you were out in Gotham tonight?”
 
Tim opened his mouth. Then closed it. Now that he thought about it, no, no he didn’t. His memory of the night was filled with exactly nothing. And before that, the day was gone, too. Tim sat, still as a statue, as if the memories would appear if he didn’t jostle them away, but his memories failed to solidify.
 
Before Tim could work himself into a panic, Batman spoke again, “It’s okay if you don’t. I just need to know.”
 
Tim gulped, his throat suddenly dry, and he shook his head, “No, I don’t remember.”
 
“Tim?” He waited for Tim to lift his head and see that Batman was now looking right back at him. “It’s going to be okay. We’ll figure this out.”
 
If there was anyone that he could confidently put all of his trust in, it would be Gotham’s resident superhero. He hadn’t started sneaking around Gotham with a camera just because of the cool photos he’d get. Batman and Robin gave Gotham hope and Tim had wanted to capture that before he even knew who they were.
 
Tim took a steadying breath. “Okay.”
 
Batman turned his attention back out the windshield. “We’re here.”
 
When Tim turned to look too, his heart just about stopped. Laid out before them was what could only be the fabled Batcave. Tim. Was in. The Batcave. He sat frozen, his mouth agape, until the door beside him opened and Batman gestured for him to follow him out. Into. The.  Batcave.  Tim almost forgot to unbuckle himself in his haste to scramble out of the car.
 
Forget whatever memories he was missing. No moment in his life was  ever  going to be cooler than  this  . As long as he got to keep  this  memory, those other memories could be lost forever for all Tim cared.
 
He tried turning in place to see it all as Batman ushered him across the massive space, but he’d barely taken two steps before he tripped over the cloak pooling around his feet. He would’ve face-planted if Batman hadn’t righted him with steady hands. “Careful.”
 
They were approaching the biggest computer Tim had ever seen when a voice called out, “Hey B, is that you?”
 
Tim turned in time to see a figure in dark body armor and a leather jacket limp past a hospital curtain. His green eyes landed first on Batman then made a slow descent until they were fixed on Tim. Neither Tim nor the stranger moved for a long moment.
 
And then the man burst out laughing, bright and gleeful. Tim’s jaw dropped.
 
“ Robin?! ”
 
His hero cut off mid-laugh and froze, smile fixed in place but cracked.  Oh crap. 
 
Tim instantly smacked his cloak-concealed hands over his face and yelped, “I didn’t see! I won’t tell anyone! I didn’t see your face, I promise! I’m sorry!”
 
The other side of the cave was silent.
 
“Oh, Tim,” Batman placed a hand on Tim’s shoulder and started gently guiding him away, “it’s okay.” There was no way that was true. “How about we get you into some clothes, how’s that sound?” Probably less embarrassing but that couldn’t fix what had just happened. “I can check something while you do that and then we can talk.” Everything was thoroughly ruined and it was  all his fault .
 
Tim still had his face buried because his eyes were betraying him and he could  not  cry in front of Batman. He tried to keep his voice steady as he sniffled, “I really didn’t see. Please—please don’t erase my memories. I promise I don’t know who you are, and I wouldn’t tell anyone ever if I did.”
 
“I believe you.”
 
The statement was so simple, but it had Tim jerking his head up to stare at Batman.
 
“I believe you, Tim. Now let’s get you into some clothes. Hood,” he looked toward Robin  the man  who was definitely Jason Todd even if he was older , “go sit down and put ice back on your knee.”
 
Tim was led into a locker room and handed a small bundle of clothes while he tried to discreetly wipe at his eyes.
 
“Take all the time you need and come out when you’re ready,” Batman told him before he left Tim alone.
 
Tim took a moment to compose himself.
 
 Come on, kid. Nothin’ fell apart. Everything’s okay. Batman ain’t mad at you. He wouldn’t lie.  Well, maybe he would lie, but Tim didn’t think so. A smile twitched at the corner of Tim’s mouth. He needed to stop playing Robin in his head when the real Robin was right out in the cave. He could go back out once he was dressed and maybe meet him before he had to leave. It would be fine.
 
Batman really  didn’t  seem mad at him for accidentally seeing Robin without his mask, and he was being very, very nice to Tim. It was… refreshing. He wanted to have more of that before he was taken home. With that thought in mind, he threw the clothes on as quickly as he could. The clothes were all just a little too big for him, but he didn’t have the time to care.
 
When he scampered back out of the locker room, mood significantly lighter, he saw that Batman was sitting at the big computer, talking quietly—presumably to someone through the comm—and typing periodically. Tim slowed his approach and stopped a couple feet behind where Batman was sitting. His eyes were drawn to a seemingly stationary black and white picture when it appeared on the screen. His instincts told him that he should really hang back and avoid snooping, but his curiosity was burning brightly, so he stayed quiet and snuck closer.
 
It took Tim a moment to notice that there were lights in the back of the picture that were moving periodically, and a moment longer to identify them as headlights from cars on the street. The camera was pointed steadily at an alleyway and Tim leaned a little closer when he realized that he recognized it. It was a fairly clear shot of the alley in which he had awoken. So far, the alley was empty.
 
They didn’t have to wait long before a black shape dropped gracefully into the frame, landing in a crouch and turning quickly. The picture was frustratingly low-quality, but Tim could make out enough to see flickers of movement as they threw things at something out of view of the camera. When the figure flipped backward, Tim perked up slightly, wondering if maybe he was watching Nightwing, but he quickly discarded the idea. Even without color, the costume was all wrong. Regardless, the part of the fight he could see was captivating to watch.
 
Tim winced in sympathy when the darkly clad fighter dropped the long pole in his hands in favor of clutching his wrist. It took only a moment for him to recover, but in that time, another person had advanced on them from off-camera. Tim squinted at the screen. It looked like the new person—clothes mostly obscured in shadow except for a tall top hat—was shimmering.
 
With no sound, Tim couldn’t tell what they were saying, but it looked like they were talking. Now that he was standing still, Tim got a much better look at the fighter’s costume. Most of the suit looked gray when washed of color by the surveillance camera. There were dark bands crossed over his uniform leading to his head covering of a half-face mask. It actually looked kind of familiar… Oh! Tim should’ve recognized the cowl from the cloak he had left in the locker room right away. Something settled in Tim’s chest. It  hadn’t  been Robin that had found him, but this unknown person instead.
 
His eyes were drawn to the subtle movement of the fighter’s arm and Tim realized that he was slowly reaching for something on his belt, but before he could enact whatever his plan was, the shadowed figure pulled the top hat from their head and it started to glow.
 
The masked fighter reacted instantly, bursting into motion as he threw something down the alleyway and tried to dodge with a flip. It could’ve looked really cool. A true shame, though, that the magic missile shot him straight on, even as he struggled his hardest to avoid it. Quite rude of the magician, honestly.
 
The alley camera whited-out the instant the beam struck and it took a few long seconds for the picture to readjust to the darkness of the alley. When it did, it revealed…
 
That couldn’t be right. Right there on the screen was Tim’s own crumpled form, wrapped as he had been when he woke up.
 
Before Tim could question technical glitches and such, Batman turned in his chair. “Tim, may I see your wrist?”
 
His hands were exceedingly gentle when he took Tim’s forearm in his hand and pulled up the sleeve to reveal the wound that had been there since Tim woke up. While Batman frowned at the gash on Tim’s wrist, Tim’s mind was screeching to a halt.
 
“I—I don’t understand.”
 
Batman looked up to study Tim through the eyes of the cowl. At least, Tim thought he was looking at him—it was kind of hard to tell. The dark knight pursed his lips, releasing Tim’s wrist and standing. “Come with me. I’ll explain.”
 
Tim was being led to the curtained area Jason had come from. While they walked, Batman brought a hand up to his ear again. “Oracle, Code Dawn confirmed. Update everyone on the situation. And please try to keep everyone out for a bit longer if you can.”
 
Older Jason was still there, reclined on one of the many beds. He had a plastic bag of ice resting on his knee, and he looked up from a book in his hand when they entered. His eyes found Batman first before taking a long time to move down to him. Tim wasn’t  that  short, was he?
 
“B?”
 
Batman ignored him, scooping Tim up under his arms and setting him at the edge of the hospital bed next to Jason’s.
 
“Tim,” Batman started, seeming to pick over his words carefully. “You know Jason Todd here,” he said, gesturing behind him as he reached to pull over a rolling cart with his other hand.
 
Tim’s eyes widened. “No!” he protested too quickly, looking away.
 
“It’s okay, Tim. I know you know me, too,” and then Batman did the last thing Tim expected. He tugged the cowl off his head, revealing the face of Bruce Wayne. Tim’s jaw dropped as he stared into his blue eyes which were filled with a surprising amount of warmth. “But we look older than you remember, correct?”
 
Tim felt overwhelmed as he looked between the two of them. Batman and Robin. Bruce Wayne and Jason Todd. Both showing signs of age that hadn’t been there until tonight.
 
Thoughts were swirling in Tim’s head, but he finally managed to ask his most important question, “How do you know what I know?”
 
“We’ve known for many years actually. Because we’ve known  you  for many years.”
 
“What—”
 
“B,” Jason cut in, “stop being cryptic; you’re gonna freak the kid out.”
 
“I’m trying to explain—”
 
“Bitty bird, we’re older than you recognize because you got shrunk… somehow. Not important. So you forgot a lot of stuff, like knowing us and all that jazz. Normally, you’re much older than you are right now. Not that much taller though.”
 
Mr. Wayne didn’t even glance up from cleaning Tim’s wrist when he chastised, “Jason.”
 
“ Fine , you’re a perfectly normal height when you’re older. Happy?”
 
Tim’s brain was running a mile a minute as he processed all of that.
 
“He…” Tim started hesitantly, trying to settle on a question, “he called you Hood earlier, right? Are you not Robin in the future?”
 
“First off, this is the present, not the future. And no, I’m not Robin anymore. I haven’t been for a long time.”
 
“Why not?” Tim asked with a frown, leaning forward. “You’re an amazing Robin, so why did you stop?”
 
Seeing the cracked look in Jason’s eyes again, Tim regretted asking.
 
Mr. Wayne’s hands stilled on the bandages on his arm, and he opened his mouth, probably to intervene.
 
Before he could, however, Jason replied, “I grew out of it. And the next person to fill the pixie boots was just as good.”Tim frowned deeper, “You are—were perfect at it. There’s no way the next Robin was better.”
 
Jason’s smile looked pained, “I used to think that too. But do you know who the next Robin after me was, bitty bird? You.”
 
Tim felt like his brain was melting. “But—but—but… But I have parents!”
 
“Somehow you made it work,” Jason said, his smirk becoming more natural as he teased Tim.
 
And wasn’t that just crazy? Jason Todd, now former Robin, was teasing him like this was a normal thing that happened. Maybe it was.
 
A rumbling sound began filling the vast space of the cave and Tim looked around, disconcerted, unsure where it was coming from.
 
“That would be Dick getting back,” Mr. Wayne said, taping the bandage in place on his wrist and stepping back.
 
“I’m honestly surprised he managed to stay away for this long,” Jason said, fighting to be heard over the roar of the engine as the noise peaked.
 
The cacophony of noise cut out as the engine was shut off and they hardly had to wait ten seconds before a black and blue clad figure was bounding into the curtained medbay.
 
“Why did nobody tell me you found—” Nightwing skidded to a halt and froze, presumably taking in Tim. His jaw dropped as he gasped, “Oh my gosh he’s so small! B, what can we tell him? Does he know about us?”
 
“He knows.”
 
Even a few years older, Dick Grayson’s smile was as bright as the day Tim first saw it. “Then Tim, I have a super important question for you.”
 
Tim nodded seriously, if a bit apprehensively, “Okay?”
 
“Can I give you a hug?”
 
Jason snorted and put a hand over his face. 
 
That was the first thing Dick wanted to know?
 
“Sure?” Tim said, feeling more confused by the second.
 
When Dick’s arms came to wrap around him, Tim’s confusion was put right out of his mind in favor of savoring the feeling. His arms felt warm and sturdy and so, so safe that Tim practically melted against Dick’s chest.
 
The crowning moment was when Dick pressed a soft kiss to his hair. If Tim had less self control, he might’ve started bawling then and there. He still kind of wanted to, but instead he closed his eyes and brought his arms around the eldest Robin to squeeze him back like he was probably supposed to.
 
“Jay, Bruce, he’s the perfect size for hugging! You’ll need to hug him too when I’m done.”
 
“Christ, Big Bird, don’t let Damian hear you say that. They’re about the same size.”
 
Turning his head so his face wasn’t so buried in Dick’s chest, Tim asked, “Who’s Damian?”
 
“Drake,” a young voice said behind him, sounding offended, “what is the meaning of this? Why are you a child?”
 
“B, you’re not allowed to yell at me anymore when I call him a demon, because we mentioned him and he  appeared  . It’s a  sign ,” Jason insisted, completely ignoring the newcomer’s questions.
 
Mr. Wayne gave a long-suffering sigh before ignoring Jason in favor of answering the questions. “Tim got hit with a spell that apparently made him young. He doesn’t remember being older than this, so please be nice.”
 
Tim began the process of disentangling himself from Dick’s arms in order to face the boy who looked to be about his age. Instead of letting him go fully, Dick set Tim on his lap, holding him comfortably but loosely, allowing him to get up if he wanted. He didn’t.
 
The dark haired boy walked forward and stopped right in front of him, looking him over with an assessing eye. His skin was darker than any of theirs, and his eyes were a brilliant green. As those eyes roved over him, Tim felt nervousness grow in his stomach, suddenly worried he was being tested and he was going to fail. What would even happen if that happened? Unless his parents knew he was a… was a vigilante, he couldn’t go home like this.
 
Then the boy stuck out his hand, assessment apparently finished as quickly as it had started. “Damian Al Ghul-Wayne. Pleased to make your acquaintance. How old are you?”
 
“Um, I’m ten and a half.” That earned him a little squeeze from the arms around him and a soft ‘ so little ’ from Dick.
 
“So I’m older than you. Good to know.”
 
“Yeah, yeah, Demon Brat. Enjoy it while it lasts—”
 
“Jason,” Mr. Wayne said in a warning tone.
 
“ Anyway ,” Dick cut in, drawing the attention of everyone in the room to himself and subsequently Tim, “it’s pretty late and we should be getting to bed. We can worry about things in the morning.”
 
Damian clicked his tongue. “It’s already morning. While you two were out looking for Drake, I, left behind for  no  discernable reason, slept soundly and am now awake for the day.”
 
From the other bed, Jason was looking skeptically at Damian, but kept his thoughts to himself.
 
“Well  I’m  going to take Timmy with me to bed, and you’re gonna sleep too, B,” Dick said, leaving no room for arguments.
 
“I’m, uh,” Tim started shyly, not wanting to be rude by correcting him. At Dick’s questioning hum he continued, “I’m not tired at all. I don’t think I could go to sleep now even if I tried.”
 
“Aww,” Dick whined light-heartedly. “I guess I’ll just have to see you when I wake up.”
 
As Jason shifted toward the edge of the bed, he said, “I’ll escort Timbit upstairs. You two need to shower and change.”Dick and Mr. Wayne both opened their mouths to protest, but Damian beat them, scoffing, “Don’t be preposterous, Todd, you took a pipe to the knee and are lucky your bones are so dense nothing was broken. You are in no shape to escort anyone anywhere. I can handle one child. Come along, Drake.” With that, Damian turned and walked away. Seeing no preferable options, Tim scrambled down to the floor and chased after him.
 
“He’s so  cute! ” Dick exclaimed quietly as he retreated.
 
“Careful, though,” Jason replied, “he’s so short I keep looking right over him. Try not to step on him.”
 
Any replies to his warning were lost to Tim as they got too far away to hear. Damian hesitated for a moment when they passed the stairs before leading them into an elevator a short distance away. As soon as the door shut, Damian turned to him.
 
“What have you been told about your future? I don’t want to try conversing with you until I know you can keep up.”
 
Tim scowled. What was it Jason called him? Demon Brat? The nickname seemed pretty appropriate, but Tim wasn’t about to say that out loud.
 
“Jason’s not Robin anymore, and I became Robin after him.”
 
Damian was silent, waiting for him to continue. When he didn’t, he clucked his tongue, “That’s it? Disgraceful. Come, I’ll tell you more over breakfast.”
 
It was just past 6am when Tim followed Damian into the kitchen of Wayne Manor. Which was apparently right above the Batcave.
 
“Good morning, Pennyworth,” Damian said politely, nodding to the Waynes’ beloved butler, Alfred Pennyworth, “Drake got himself shrunk, so I’ll be escorting him around today. Drake, you may take a seat over here.”
 
Tim wasn’t sure what he was feeling, but he was definitely reconsidering a nap with Dick. He seemed like better company.
 
“You, Timothy Drake, became Robin after Jason—”
 
“Master Damian, I’m going to stop you there.” Mr. Pennyworth approached them at the kitchen table, two plates of food in hand. “You would do well to avoid upsetting Master Tim. The broader strokes should be fine.”
 
“Of course,” Damian conceded. “You became Robin and began spending more of your time here than at your house. I won’t get into too great detail,” he said, glancing past the kitchen island to where Mr. Pennyworth had gone back to work, “but you came under my father’s guardianship when it became necessary, and later you were adopted into the family. You were still Robin when I—”
 
“Wait, wait,  what ? I—I live here? I’m—” Tim couldn’t continue. His eyes were wide as he stared at Damian across the table.
 
“Yes, you live here some of the time. You also have an apartment in the city. If you ask, I can tell you about your parents, but I would like to avoid upsetting you.”
 
Tim took a sip of water from the water glass before him, trying to clear his tight throat before speaking quietly, “I’m… part of your family? Mr. Wayne cared enough to adopt me?”
 
Damian’s eyes widened and he seemed at a loss for words when the first tear dripped down Tim’s cheek.
 
“Oh hush now, dear boy,” Mr. Pennyworth said as he came back over, taking the chair to Tim’s left. He gently patted Tim’s back and dabbed at his tears with a handkerchief. “We all care very much about you. All of the Masters of the house were ready to tear Gotham apart to find you when you went missing during patrol last night. You’ll come to learn that you are very cared for and very, very loved.”
 
Oh yeah, like  that  was going to get him to stop crying. It took an embarrassingly long few minutes for Tim to get control of himself, all the while having his back rubbed soothingly.
 
Tim gave one last sniffle before giving a watery smile to the old butler, “Thank you, Mr. Pennyworth.”
 
He tutted, shaking his head, “Please, Master Tim, call me Alfred. And while we’re on the subject, Master Bruce will insist on you calling him Bruce as well. None of this “Mr. Wayne” tosh. Now, you boys finish your breakfast. And have a splendid day.”
 
A splendid day with his heroes who were also his family. He was sure he could do that.
 
 
The sky was dark once more when Dick turned off the TV in the den late that night.
 
Tim was dozing in a blanket against Dick’s chest when his big brother carefully shifted him into his arms and started for the stairs. He pressed a kiss to Tim’s hair and asked quietly, “Hey Timmy, where do you want to sleep?”
 
Tim lifted a hand out of the blanket to rub at a droopy eye while he considered. Just when Dick was about to decide for him, Tim asked, “Can I sleep in Big Tim’s room?”
 
Dick gave a soft huff of laughter and commented, “I’m not sure I’ll be able to find the bed, but we can try.”
 
Even holding Tim, he opened the door easily, revealing a cluttered, seemingly disorganized mess inside. He waded through the junk on the floor to deposit Tim softly on a corner of the bed. Tim curled tighter in the blanket as Dick moved around him, clearing space for him to slip under the covers, but Tim was determinedly trying to wake up, remembering that there was something he needed to do before he could sleep. When Tim sat up but made no move to get in the bed when Dick slid the covers down, Dick gave his shoulder a little squeeze.
 
“Something wrong? Did Timmy fall down the well?” His smile was filled with so much love that Tim thought he would burst for a second.
 
Tim returned the smile shyly and shook his head. “I just need to do something before I can go to bed.”
 
“Okay. Don’t stay up too late, though. Little Timmys need their sleep.” Tim reveled in the kiss pressed to his hair, soaking up as much warmth from it as he could before Dick pulled away.
 
“Holler if you need anything. Sweet dreams.”
 
“Good night,” Tim called softly as Dick shut the door behind him.
 
Blanket still around his shoulders, Tim climbed carefully off the bed and approached the desk. It only took him a moment to find a notebook with some blank pages that hopefully wouldn’t be missed when he tore them out. He only managed to find a pen amidst the clutter on the desk, but he began writing with it anyway. His mission was too important to worry about such things. 
 
He was little for now. He couldn’t help them track down a magician or fight crime. But  this  was something he could do. Just to make sure. Because it suddenly felt like the most important thing in the world to make sure he didn’t forget.
 
Maybe his older self already knew. Maybe he’d remember being Tim-sized after they fixed him. Or maybe he needed to be reminded. To hear about the things he might be overlooking.
 
 

 Dear Big Tim, 

 

 I don’t know if you’re going to remember being me-sized, so I wanted to write this to you in case you forget. I got to meet (most) our siblings which was super super cool. Dick went to bed soon after I met him because it was really early morning when we got back to the Batcave, but I wasn’t tired so I went upstairs. Damian (who I learned is Robin now (after us!)) went with us to tell us about being grown up. 

 
 Damian kept commenting today on how he’s older than me right now; he seemed to really enjoy it. It only got a little annoying when I was trying to cut up an orange for a snack, and he wouldn’t let me use the knife, so he had to do it. Once I had my orange slices though, he took me around the manor to meet his pets. They were really cute. I didn’t get to meet “Batcow” because    Mr.W    Bruce doesn’t want me going back down to the Cave until his magician friend gets here. Instead, we went to the library and Alfred (the cat) sat on my lap and made me fall asleep. I think Damian must’ve been petting Alfred (the cat) after I fell asleep because he was sleeping against the couch when I woke up. Jason says he took a lot of pictures, so watch out for that. 
 

 Jason acts really differently from when he was Robin. He seems lonely. He told me that Alfred is making him stay at the manor while his leg heals, but I don’t think he comes over enough when he doesn’t have to. You should visit him. He seems like a really cool older brother to have. 

 

 The three of us ended up playing Scrabble, which Jason’s really really good at, but I bet you knew that already. He only played one game (which he definitely won), and let me and Damian keep going while he read a book on the couch. He fell asleep after a little while, and Damian took pictures, so you can ask to see those if you don’t remember. Damian called them blackmail, but I don’t think that’s what blackmail means. It’s just pictures of people sleeping. We do that every day. 

 

 Bruce and Dick were awake by the time we had lunch. I got to hear more about the time between me and you, including learning that we go by Red Robin now. I really like the name, by the way. It’s like a combination of Dick’s old name and Jason’s current name, while being uniquely us. I hope the restaurant isn’t mad though. 

 
 At night, Dick let me sit on his lap while we watched a movie. Remember when we did that at the circus the first time we met him? I hope you do. He was really excited to show me  Frozen  because he said it was a movie you really like, and he wanted me to see it for the first time again. Just between us, I think he might’ve been lying because I thought it was only okay. Sorry if you really like that movie though. 
 

 His hugs are the absolute best. I hope you get a lot of them because I don’t think I could ever get enough. 

 
 I didn’t get to meet Barbara (who I learned isn’t Batgirl anymore) or Cassandra (who I really wanted to meet because I’ve always wanted a sister) or Stephanie (who spent time as Robin  and  Batgirl and I would love to hear the comparison between those two roles). Everybody avoided the topic of why Barbara stopped being Batgirl but they said she still works with Batman. If you could, would you tell her that I thought she was awesome as Batgirl, but I bet what she’s doing now is really good too? And that I’m sorry I couldn’t meet Cassandra or Stephanie? 
 
 It’s really nice to know that   you   we have a big family. I’ve really enjoyed getting to know all of them. Today has me filled up with so much love from all the people in your life showering their love for you on to me. 
 

 I decided to write to you to let you know what I got to see today that you might not notice. I’d love it if you already think about these things all the time, but I couldn’t stand the thought of you forgetting that the life you’re living is what I dream about. 

 

 I hope you remember to enjoy the feeling of flying on grappling hooks around Gotham. I hope you see your family whenever you want just because you can. I hope you remember to tell them you love them. I hope their love feels like second-nature to you. But I also hope you remember to stop sometimes to really take it in. Don’t take the things in your life for granted. And especially, don’t overlook the little things.
